The University of Peradeniya hosts nine faculties (including the newly added Management faculty), two postgraduate institutes, 10 centres, 73 departments, and teaches about 11,000 students in the fields of Medicine, Agriculture, Arts, Science, Engineering, Dental Sciences, Veterinary Medicine and Animal Science, Management and Allied Health Science.{{cite web | url=http://www.pdn.ac.lk/overview/history_more.html | title=Faculties, Postgraduate Institutes and Centres of the University of Peradeniya in the year 2002 | publisher=University of Peradeniya | year=2002 | accessdate=2010-05-24 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110116001155/http://www.pdn.ac.lk/overview/history_more.html | archive-date=16 January 2011 | dead-url=yes | df=dmy-all }} It claims to have the largest government endowment by a higher education institution in Sri Lanka, based on its large staff and faculties/departments.{{cite web|url=http://www.ugc.ac.lk/en/statistics/university-system-at-a-glance.html |title=University System at a Glance |publisher=[[University Grants Commission (Sri Lanka)]] |year=2009 |accessdate=2010-05-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100418074417/http://www.ugc.ac.lk/en/statistics/university-system-at-a-glance.html |archivedate=18 April 2010 }} ==Ranking== In 2016 University of Peradeniya has been ranked by [http://www.mohe.gov.lk/index.php/en/component/university/?view=rank 1st]{{cite web |url=http://www.mohe.gov.lk/index.php/en/component/university/?view=rank|title=Ministry of Higher Education|publisher= |accessdate=27 Sep 2016}} place for excellence. In Sri Lanka University of Peradeniya has been ranked in [http://www.mohe.gov.lk/index.php/en/component/university/?view=rank 2nd] place for total evaluated rank. This has been published by [http://www.webometrics.info Webometrics]{{cite web|url=http://www.webometrics.info/en/Asia/Sri%20Lanka%20|title=Sri Lanka - Ranking Web of Universities |accessdate=27 Sep 2016}} in September 2016. In 2013 University of Peradeniya was ranked #1 in Sri Lanka in research by [[ResearchGate]].{{cite web|url=https://www.researchgate.net/institutions/Sri_Lanka|title=Institutions|publisher=|accessdate=18 July 2015}} In 2010, according to University Ranking by Academic Performance (URAP),{{Cite web|url=http://www.urapcenter.org/2010|title=URAP - University Ranking by Academic Performance}} University of Peradeniya ranked 1426th in the world. It is the only Sri Lankan university ranked under URAP.http://www.urapcenter.org/2011/university.php?q=University of Peradeniya ==Location== On a site that touches the lower slopes of the lush [[Hanthana mountain range]], University of Peradeniya is known for its natural environment.{{fact|date=July 2018}} It has inspired intellectuals like [[Professor|Prof.]] [[Ediriweera Sarachchandra]], Sri Lanka's premium playwright.{{cite web|url=http://www.frontlineonnet.com/fl1604/16040710.htm |title=Symposium: Sri Lanka's Culture Experience – Between Home and the World |publisher=Frontline |year=1999 |accessdate=2011-01-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070929092341/http://www.frontlineonnet.com/fl1604/16040710.htm |archivedate=29 September 2007 }} The university is in the [[Central Province of Sri Lanka|Central Province]], 8 km from the sacred city of [[Kandy]] (the historic capital of the last kingdom of Sri Lanka) and about 110 km from [[Colombo]]. A tourist attraction, [[Botanical Garden of Peradeniya]] is close by. The university spans nearly 700 hectares in the Mahaweli flood plain. Most of the area remains afforested. Climate around the university is mild, and the temperature fluctuates between 18 and 30 degrees Celsius. The main entrance to the university is through [[Galaha]] road. The [[Faculty of Engineering, University of Peradeniya|Faculty of Engineering]] is on one side of the [[Mahaweli River]] and all other faculties are on the other side. The Akbar bridge links the two banks of the river. Considered as a marvel of civil engineering, it was designed by late [[Professor|Prof.]] A. Thurairajah (Dean of the Faculty of Engineering, 1975–77 and 1982–85) and built by the first batch of the faculty, in the year of its inception. The Sarasavi Uyana railway station is on campus. Another bridge known as Yaka Paalama links the railway to the other bank. Daily shuttle bus services operate from Kandy to Galaha junction and Kandy to the university. A separate subcampus was established in 1968 at Mahailuppallama, [[North Central Province, Sri Lanka|North Central province]] for the Faculty of Agriculture.{{cite web | url=http://www.pdn.ac.lk/agri/history/ | title=Faculty of Agriculture sub campus | publisher=Faculty of Agriculture, University of Peradeniya | year=2008 | accessdate=2010-05-24 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101127165951/http://www.pdn.ac.lk/agri/history/ | archivedate=27 November 2010 | df=dmy-all }} Separate residential facilities are provided to this subcampus. {{See also|Campus of University of Peradeniya}} ==History== ===Beginnings=== The proposal for the establishment of [[University of Ceylon]], the first university of Sri Lanka (the predecessor of University of Peradeniya) goes back to 1899. But no progress was seen until the formation of Ceylon University Association in 1906 under the guidance of Sir [[Ponnambalam Arunachalam]], [[Sir]] [[James Peiris]] and Sir [[Marcus Fernando]]. Its request for a European-style university in Sri Lanka was partially granted by the [[British Ceylon|British rulers]] with the formation of Ceylon University College on 1 January 1921. The [[University Council]], through which the administration of the Ceylon University College was done, appointed committees to plan the academic activities of a future university. It made suggestions to build the university in Bullers Road (now Bauddhaloka Mawatha) in Colombo, but it was disputed by politicians. To resolve the conflict, the then [[Governor]] [[Hugh Clifford]] appointed a committee headed by Justice M.T. Akbar on 20 December 1926. It suggested that the proposed university should be unitary, residential and outside Colombo. Another committee was appointed in 1928 with Sir Walter Buchanan-Riddel as chairman. It proposed a site at [[Aruppola]], in the Dumbara Valley close to [[Kandy]]. [[Dr.]] S.C. Paul and Andreas Nell pointed out disadvantages in the site and proposed a larger one at Peradeniya. In 1938 the government acquired the plot and developed an area about 150 hectares (out of 700 hectares) to create the University Park.{{cite web | url=http://www.island.lk/2009/04/29/midweek3.html | title=Cambridge by the Mahaweli: Peradeniya University | publisher=The Island | year=2009 | accessdate=2010-05-24}} Although the site was acquired, no plans were made to establish the university until 1941. With the arrival of Sir [[Ivor Jennings]], as the second principal of the Ceylon University College, establishment plans were put into effect. He stressed the urgent need to move the university to Peradeniya to the Minister of Education [[C. W. W. Kannangara]] and took the initiative in the process. Thus he is considered the forefather of the University of Peradeniya.{{cite web | url=http://www.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~lkawgw/ivorj.html | title=First Vice Chancellor of University of Ceylon | publisher=Rootsweb | accessdate=2010-05-24}} ===1942 to 1952=== In 1942, the [[University of Ceylon]] was created as the first unitary, residential and autonomous university in Sri Lanka with its seat in Peradeniya, amalgamating Ceylon University College and the Medical College into a single unit with 55 academic staff members, 904 students in four faculties.{{cite web | url=http://acu.studylink.com/display/provider/provider-info.html?pid=pid-mm-01-sri014 | title=University of Peradeniya, Sri Lanka: The Association of Commonwealth Universities | publisher=[[Association of Commonwealth Universities]] | year=2009 | accessdate=2010-05-24 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716160317/http://acu.studylink.com/display/provider/provider-info.html?pid=pid-mm-01-sri014 | archive-date=16 July 2011 | dead-url=yes | df=dmy-all }}{{cite web | url=http://www.lib.pdn.ac.lk/history.htm | title=Historical Roots | publisher=[[University of Peradeniya library]] | year=2009 | accessdate=2010-05-28 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100818010829/http://www.lib.pdn.ac.lk/history.htm | archivedate=18 August 2010 | df=dmy-all }} But due to [[World War II]], the construction of buildings started in 1946. Until then, the lectures and laboratory classes were conducted in the buildings obtained from the [[Ceylon University College]] and the [[Ceylon Medical College]] in Colombo. Consultants Sir [[Patrick Abercrombie]] and Clifford Holliday did the planning and layout of the university complex. The first phase of work constituted only the development of the left bank. The building of a bridge across the [[Mahaweli River]], later known as the 'Akbar bridge', was planned by [[Professor|Prof.]] A Thurairajah. Transfer of the first batch of students, students from the Departments of Law and Agriculture and the third and fourth year students of the Department of Veterinary Science, from Colombo to Peradeniya took place in 1949. Another major move took place in 1952, with the transfer of staff and students of the [[Faculty of Arts, University of Peradeniya|Faculties of Arts and Oriental Studies]], together with the [[University of Peradeniya library|Main Library]] and the University Administration. This movement on 6 October 1952 marks the official establishment of University of Ceylon, Peradeniya. At the initial stages, vice chancellor Jennings wanted to model British universities, but met with the resistance of students who opposed the changes.{{cite web | url=http://www.dailynews.lk/2009/03/31/fea05.asp | title=Kandy in 1940s and 50s... | publisher=Daily News | year=2009 | accessdate=2011-01-14 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110117130651/http://www.dailynews.lk/2009/03/31/fea05.asp | archivedate=17 January 2011 | df=dmy-all }} ===1952 to 1972=== [[File:A Bridge Inside UoP.JPG|thumb|right|A bridge inside the university.]] Although the buildings at Peradeniya were established in 1952, the official ceremony for its inception was held on 20 April 1954, with the participation of [[Elizabeth II|Queen Elizabeth II]]. The Sri Lankan government was keen to postpone the ceremony until Queen Elizabeth II could participate. Her visit was delayed by the death of [[George VI of the United Kingdom|King George VI]]. [[Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh]] also participated in the event. He declared the university opened: {{cquote|You have remarked Mr. Chancellor, that it is not easy to open a university, because once established it is always open. However, like the shopkeepers of London during the bombing, I can declare this place to be "more open than usual..."}} Sections of the University of Ceylon, functioned in Colombo and Peradeniya acted as campuses of the same university until 1967. In 1967, these campuses were split into two. The section in Peradeniya was known as the University of Ceylon, Peradeniya, while the section in Colombo was known as University of Ceylon, Colombo. ===1972 to 1978=== [[File:UoP in May.jpg|thumb|left|The university in spring, the Senate building.]] By the University Act No. 1 of 1972, four{{citation needed|date=November 2015}} universities functioned a — Peradeniya, [[University of Colombo|Colombo]], [[Vidyodaya University|Vidyodaya]] and [[University of Kelaniya|Vidyalankara]] and the [[University of Moratuwa|Ceylon College of Technology, Katubedda, Moratuwa]] became five constituent campuses of a single structure — the University of Sri Lanka. It had one vice chancellor and five presidents for five campuses. Under this designation, University of Ceylon - Peradeniya became the University of Sri Lanka - Peradeniya Campus. This designation prevailed until 1978. === 1978 to the present === Under the Universities Act No. 16, 1978, the University of Sri Lanka was split into six independent, autonomous institutions as University of Peradeniya, [[University of Colombo]], [[University of Sri Jayewardenepura]], [[University of Kelaniya]], [[University of Moratuwa]] and [[University of Jaffna]].{{cite web |title=Universities Act - Part XX |url=http://www.ugc.ac.lk/si/policy/universities-act/46.html |publisher=[[University Grants Commission (Sri Lanka)]]}} This Act brought back some of the central features of the Ceylon University Ordinance of 1942 such as the senates, the councils and courts. ==Governance and administration== The University of Peradeniya operates under the provisions of the Universities Act No. 16 of 1978 and the Universities (Amendment) Act No. 7 of 1985. It is a [[Public university|state university]] and the undergraduate study is 100% [[Free education|free]]. Therefore, it depends on the government for much of its annual grant, which is provided by the [[University Grants Commission (Sri Lanka)|University Grants Commission (UGC)]]. Due to this, its administration is heavily influenced by the UGC. The administration is based upon that of the former [[University of Ceylon]] consisting of a dual structure of bodies: the Council (formally known as the [[University Court]] which is the governing body) and the [[Academic Senate]] (academic affairs). ===Officers === [[File:Sarachchandra Theatre.jpg|thumb|right|[[Sarachchandra open-air theatre]] of University of Peradeniya, a well known historical theatre and the only one of its kind in Sri Lanka. It was built according to the architectural style of [[Theatre of ancient Greece|ancient Greek theatres]] and named in memory of [[Ediriweera Sarachchandra]], Sri Lanka's premium playwright.]] ;[[Chancellor (education)|Chancellor]] The chancellor is the head of the university and is responsible for awarding all the [[academic degree]]s. Usually the chancellor is a distinguished person in an [[List of academic disciplines|academic discipline]]. Otherwise it is a clergy or a distinguished person in the civil society. Appointment is done by the [[President of Sri Lanka]]. The position is mainly ceremonial and duties are usually carried out by the vice chancellor. The current chancellor of the university is [[Professor (title)|Prof.]] P.W. Epasinghe. He is the IT advisor to the president of Sri Lanka ;[[Chancellor (education)|Vice chancellor]] The vice chancellor is ''[[de facto]]'' the principal academic and administrative officer of the university, responsible for management tasks. This appointment is also done by the [[President of Sri Lanka]]. The current vice chancellor is [[Professor|Prof.]] Upul B.Dissanayake, who is also the Professor of Oral Pathalogy and former head of the Department of Oral Pathalogy. The deputy vice-chancellor is Prof. Shantha Hennayake, former head of the Department of Geography. ;[[Dean (education)|Deans of Faculties]] Deans are the heads of the faculties. They are responsible for the management and the tasks carried out by the faculty. Deans are appointed by the chancellor for three years. ===List of chancellors and vice chancellors=== {{col-begin}} {{col-2}} *'''Chancellors''' *;University of Ceylon and University of Sri Lanka ** [[Andrew Caldecott|Sir Andrew Caldecott]] [1942–44] ** [[Henry Monck-Mason Moore|Sir Henry Monck-Mason Moore]] (1944–49) ** [[Herwald Ramsbotham, 1st Viscount Soulbury|Lord Soulbury]] (1949–54) ** [[Oliver Ernest Goonetilleke|Sir Oliver Goonetilleke]] (1954–62) ** [[William Gopallawa]] (1962–78) *;University of Peradeniya ** [[Junius Richard Jayewardene|J. Senaratne]] (2012-) {{col-end}} ==Faculties and institutions== {{Main article|Faculties and institutions of University of Peradeniya}} [[File:Campus lion UoP.jpg|thumb|left|A traditional lion statue in front of the senate building of the university]] {| class="toccolours" style="float:right; margin-left:1em; font-size:90%; line-height:1.4em; width:300px;" ! colspan="2" style="background:#629BAB; color:white; font-weight:bold" | '''Founding of the Faculties of the University of Peradeniya''' |- style="text-align:center; font-weight:bold;" | style="background:lavender; width:200px" | '''Faculty'''|| style="background:lavender; width:100px" | '''Year founded''' |- | colspan="2" |
|- | [[Faculty of Arts, University of Peradeniya|Faculty of Arts]] || align=center| 1942 |- | style="background:#f0f0f0" | [[Faculty of Medicine, University of Peradeniya|Faculty of Medicine]]|| style="text-align:center; background:#f0f0f0" | 1962 |- | [[Faculty of Science, University of Peradeniya|Faculty of Science]]|| align=center| 1961 |- | style="background:#f0f0f0" | [[Faculty of Dental Sciences, University of Peradeniya|Faculty of Dental Sciences]]|| style="text-align:center; background:#f0f0f0" | 1943 |- | [[Faculty of Agriculture, University of Peradeniya|Faculty of Agriculture]]|| align=center| 1947 |- | style="background:#f0f0f0" | [[Faculty of Veterinary Medicine & Animal Science, University of Peradeniya|Faculty of Veterinary Medicine and Animal Science]]|| style="text-align:center; background:#f0f0f0" | 1947 |- | [[Faculty of Engineering, University of Peradeniya|Faculty of Engineering]] || align=center| 1950 |- | style="background:#f0f0f0" | [[Faculty of Allied Health Sciences, University of Peradeniya|Faculty of Allied Health Sciences]]|| style="text-align:center; background:#f0f0f0" | 2005 | |- | [[Faculty of Management, University of Peradeniya|Faculty of Management]] || align=center| 2015 |- |} The university has eight academic [[Faculty (division)|faculties]] of study. These faculties contain 72 departments. In addition, the university has two postgraduate institutions and six affiliated centres. At the beginning, it had only three present-day faculties — the Faculty of Arts, the Faculty of Medicine and the Faculty of Science. Departments of Law and Oriental Studies functioned separately. Since then, five other faculties have been added. The latest addition is the Faculty of Allied Health Science, established in 2005. The Post-graduate Institute of Science (PGIS) and Post-graduate Institute of Agriculture (PGIA) are the institutions established in the university. PGIS is a national institute established by the [[Ministry of Education (Sri Lanka)|Ministry of Higher Education]], Sri Lanka in 1996. PGIA was established in 1975 and offers three [[Postgraduate education|postgraduate degrees]]. PGIA offers postgraduate level courses in Agricultural disciplines. In addition to these institutions, Senerath Paranavitana Teaching and Research Museum functions affiliated to the Department of Archaeology, Faculty of Arts.{{cite web | url=http://www.arts.pdn.ac.lk/courses.html | title=The Senerath Paranavitana Teaching and Research Museum | publisher=[[Faculty of Arts, University of Peradeniya]] | year=2009 | accessdate=2010-05-24 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100508005408/http://www.arts.pdn.ac.lk/courses.html | archivedate=8 May 2010 | df=dmy-all }} It was established in 1960. ==Library network== {{Main article|University of Peradeniya library}} The library is a centrally administered network of libraries. It is considered the oldest academic library in Sri Lanka.{{ref label|d|d|none}} Containing over 430,000 items, it is one of the largest libraries serving the country. Seven branches are in faculties in the main campus at Peradeniya and one other branch in Mahailuppallama subcampus. University of Peradeniya library contains a legal deposit collection of 300,000 items, special collection of 15,000+ items acquired from various individuals, [[palm-leaf manuscript]] collection of approximately 5,000 (second largest in Sri Lanka) and a [[Microform|microfilm]] collection of 17,000. Furthermore, it owns the largest historical map collection in Sri Lanka.{{cite web | url=http://www.arts.pdn.ac.lk/students.html | title=Facilities and Services: University of Peradeniya Library Network | publisher=[[Faculty of Arts, University of Peradeniya]] | year=2009 | accessdate=2010-05-28 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100616072501/http://www.arts.pdn.ac.lk/students.html | archive-date=16 June 2010 | dead-url=yes | df=dmy-all }} ==Student life== ===Student Organizations=== Students at the University of Peradeniya run over 100 [[Student society|clubs and organizations]]. These include cultural and religious groups, academic clubs, and common-interest organizations. The Peradeniya Students' Union (PSU) is considered the highest body which represents all internal students.{{cite web | url=http://www.arts.pdn.ac.lk/activities.html | title=Student Activities | publisher=University of Peradeniya | year=2008 | accessdate=2010-11-13 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101110192657/http://www.arts.pdn.ac.lk/activities.html | archive-date=10 November 2010 | dead-url=yes | df=dmy-all }} Separate student unions operate in each faculty. These student societies include: {{col-begin}} {{col-2}} * Agriculture Students Union (AgSU) ** Agriculture Management Science Society (AGMAG) ** Agriculture Faculty Media and Journalism Society (AFJM) ** Arts Circle - Faculty of Agriculture ** Inventors Club - Faculty of Agriculture ** Nature Society ** Horticulture Society ** Society of Food Science and Technology ** Biology Guild * Arts University of Peradeniya has 30 athletics teams to date. Facilities include a well-equipped gymnasium, one of the largest multi-purpose outstation stadiums in Sri Lanka, a 50m swimming pool and separate stadiums for [[cricket]], [[rugby football|rugby]], [[association football|football]], [[hockey]], [[tennis]], [[track and field]] and [[elle (sport)|elle]]. ==Residential facilities== [[File:Gal Bangalawa, University of Peradeniya.jpg|thumb|Gal Bangalawa of University of Peradeniya.]] The University of Peradeniya is the only residential university in Sri Lanka. It provides residential facilities to most of its undergraduate students, all its academic staff members and guests. Three guest houses — [[Gal Bangalawa]], Upper Hantana Guest House and Lady Hill was a tourist hotel — come under university administration. '''Total''' | 9605 || 100% |} Total number of undergraduates in the university for year 2009/10 was 9605. Student intake for that year remained 2620. In 2008, 1514 postgraduate students studied in the university, most of them affiliated to the two postgraduate institutions: Postgraduate Institute of Science (PGIS) and Postgraduate Institute of Agriculture (PGIA). Postgraduate output for the year was 358, including 15 [[Doctor of Philosophy|doctorates]]. Faculties except Science and Agriculture conducted their own postgraduate courses. Women constituted 53.15 percent of undergraduates. Women constitution remained over 45 percent in all faculties except [[Faculty of Engineering, University of Peradeniya|Faculty of Engineering]] where it was 15.46 percent.{{ref label|f|f|none}} Courses in all faculties except [[Faculty of Arts, University of Peradeniya|Faculty of Arts]] are taught in [[English language|English medium]]. It is the university in Sri Lanka that is served by the highest number of [[professor]]s, [[associate professor]]s and academic staff. Teacher to student ratio of the university was 1:13 by 2008. University of Peradeniya has been served by a number of world-class faculty. Varapragash in 1997 due to kidney failure following severe ragging by a group of eight Tamil senior students{{cite web | url=http://noragnofear.com/index.html | title=Death of S. Varapragash | publisher=noragnofear.com | year=2008 | accessdate=2010-05-24 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090228191019/http://noragnofear.com/index.html | archivedate=28 February 2009 | df=dmy-all }} and the permanent disability of Rupa Rathnaseeli in 1975 as a result of having jumped from the second floor of the hostel Ramanathan Hall to escape the physical ragging by the seniors. She committed suicide in 2002.{{cite web | url=http://www.island.lk/2003/01/11//news01.html | title=Rupa Rathnaseeli, forced to jump from the second floor of the ''Ramanathan'' | publisher=The Island | year=2007 | accessdate=2010-05-24}} In 1997, Selvanayagam Varapragash, a first-year engineering student was murdered on the campus due to hazing. He was subjected to sadistic ragging, and in the post-mortem a large quantity of toothpaste was found in his rectum.{{citation needed|date=July 2015}} ==Popular culture== [[File:Uni trees.jpg|thumb|left|Serene road inside university]] The University of Peradeniya holds a central position in classical university education, which has made it the setting for many dramas, films, songs, poems, novels and other cultural works in Sri Lanka.{{cite web | url=http://www.sundayobserver.lk/2003/11/02/fea03.html | title=Sarath Amunugama's ''Maname Mathakvi'' The Return to Peradeniya | publisher=The Sunday Observer | year=2003 | accessdate=2010-06-13 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930181539/http://www.sundayobserver.lk/2003/11/02/fea03.html | archivedate=30 September 2007 | df=dmy-all }}Book Review: Peradeniya-Memories of a University. Edited by K.M. de Silva and Tissa Jayatillaka. Reviewed by [[Jayantha Dhanapala]]{{cite web | url=http://sundaytimes.lk/980517/plus9.html | title=More than just a nostalgic voyage down memory lane | publisher=The Sunday Times | year=1998 | accessdate=2010-06-13}} Songs like "Hanthanata paayana sanda..." by Amarasiri Peiris, "Hanthane kandu muduna sisara..." by [[W. D. Amaradeva]], "Hanthana adaviye meduru kulunu sudu sandaluthalaa pisa..." by [[Nanda Malini]], "Mé nagaraya maa oba munagasunu nagarayayi..." by Mervin Perera, "Hanthane raja dahane...", "Nethu saluna...", "Hantana Desin ena..." are only a few of them. Movies like [[Gamini Fonseka]]'s ''Saagarayak Meda'' (In the middle of an ocean) and Sugathapala Senarath Yapa's ''[[Hanthane Kathawa]]'' (The story of Hanthana) are directly based on University of Peradeniya. UoP is featured in novels: [[Siri Gunasinghe]]'s ''Sevanella'' (The shadow) and [[Gunadasa Amarasekara]]'s ''Ek Sathya Kathawak'' (One true story). Groundbreaking dramas like [[Professor|Prof.]] [[Ediriweera Sarachchandra]]'s ''Maname'' (1957) and ''Sinhabahu'' (1960) were first directed and played there.{{cite web | url=http://www.island.lk/2004/03/21/featur07.html | title=Celebrating Creativity: Applause at the Wendt | publisher=The Island | year=2007 | accessdate=2010-05-24}} In Sarachchandra's novel ''Heta Echchara Kaluvara Nae'' (Tomorrow is not that dark), an entire chapter is dedicated to describe the beauty of the university. ==Further reading== * De Silva, K. revision.comment: Daniel Dennett
revision.text:
The '''user illusion''' is the illusion created for the user by a [[human-computer interface|human–computer interface]], for example the [[desktop metaphor|visual metaphor of a desktop]] used in many [[graphical user interfaces]]. The phrase originated at [[Xerox PARC]].<ref>{{cite book|author=Bruce Tognazzini|authorlink=Bruce Tognazzini|title=Tog on Software Design|isbn=0-201-48917-1|year=1996|publisher=Addison-Wesley Professional|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UKBQAAAAMAAJ}}</ref>
Some [[Philosophy of mind|philosophers of mind]] have argued that [[consciousness]] is a form of user illusion. This notion is explored by [[Tor Nørretranders]] in his 1991 Danish book ''Mærk verden'', issued in a 1998 English edition as ''The User Illusion: Cutting Consciousness Down to Size''.<ref>{{cite book|author=Tor Nørretranders|authorlink=Tor Nørretranders|title=The User Illusion: Cutting Consciousness Down to Size|isbn=0-670-87579-1|year=1998|publisher=Viking|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TwMwAAAAMAAJ}}</ref> He introduced the idea of [[exformation]] in this book. Philosopher [[Daniel Dennett]] has also embraced the view that human consciousness is a "user-illusion."<ref>"Human consciousness is unlike all other varieties of animal consciousness in that it is a product in large part of cultural evolution . . . creating thereby a cognitive architecture unlike the ‘bottom-up’ minds of animals. . . . [T]his architecture furnishes each of us with . . . a user-illusion” (Daniel C. Dennett, ''From Bacteria to Bach and Back: The Evolution of Minds'' (2017), p. 370).</ref>
According to this picture, our experience of the world is not immediate, as all sensation requires processing time. It follows that our conscious experience is less a perfect reflection of what is occurring, and more a simulation produced unconsciously by the brain. Therefore, there may be phenomena that exist beyond our peripheries, beyond what consciousness could create to isolate or reduce them.
== Criticism == Critics of the idea of consciousness being a device for justifying preconceptions argue that such a device would consume [[nutrient]]s without producing any useful results, since it would not change the outcome of any decisions. These critics argue that the existence of [[social insect]]s with extremely small brains [[falsifiability|falsifies]] the notion that social behavior requires consciousness, citing that insects have too small [[brain]]s to be conscious and yet there are observed behaviors among them that for all functional intents and purposes match those of complex social cooperation and manipulation (including hierarchies where each individual has its place among [[paper wasp]]s and [[Jack Jumper]] [[ant]]s and [[honey bee]]s sneaking when they lay eggs). These critics also argue that since social behavior in insects and other extremely small-brained animals have [[convergent evolution|evolved multiple times independently]], there is no evolutionary difficulty in simple reaction sociality to impose selection pressure for the more nutrient-consuming path of consciousness for sociality. These critics do point out that other evolutionary paths to consciousness are possible, such as critical evaluation that enhances plasticity by criticizing [[fallibility|fallible]] notions, while pointing out that such a critical consciousness would be quite different from the justificatory type proposed by Nørretranders, differences including that a critical consciousness would make individuals more capable of changing their minds instead of justifying and persuading.<ref>How the body shapes the way we think: A new view of intelligence, Rolf Pfeifer, Josh Bongard</ref><ref>Information Processing in Social Insects: Claire Detrain, Jean L. Deneubourg, Jacques M. Pasteels</ref><ref>Thinking, Fast and Slow; Daniel Kahneman</ref><ref>Asking the Right Questions: A Guide to Critical Thinking; M. Neil Browne</ref><ref>The Art of Thinking Clearly; Rolf Dobelli</ref>
